## Commercial Upgrade â€” Complete Delivery Summary

### Architecture change: `app/[locale]/` routing
Every URL is now locale-prefixed (`/zh/products`, `/en/products`, `/ja/products`). The `middleware.ts` auto-detects browser language and redirects. `app/layout.tsx` is a bare shell; `app/[locale]/layout.tsx` sets `<html lang>`, wraps with `NextIntlClientProvider`, and mounts `Navbar`, `CartDrawer`, and `LeadCaptureModal`.

### New files created

| File | Purpose |
|---|---|
| `middleware.ts` | Locale detection + redirect |
| `i18n/routing.ts` | Defines `['zh','en','ja']` locales |
| `i18n/request.ts` | Maps locale to message file |
| `i18n/navigation.ts` | Locale-aware `Link`, `useRouter`, `usePathname` |
| `messages/zh.json` + `en.json` + `ja.json` | ~200 translated strings each |
| `app/sitemap.ts` | Dynamic sitemap for all locales Ã— all pages |
| `public/robots.txt` | SEO robots config |
| `lib/analytics.ts` | `trackEvent()` â€” fire-and-forget, session ID via localStorage |
| `components/PageTracker.tsx` | Client component for server page tracking |
| `app/[locale]/admin/page.tsx` + `AdminDashboardClient.tsx` | Recharts funnel chart + stats + leads table |
| `app/[locale]/lp/layout.tsx` | LP layout (no Navbar) |
| `app/[locale]/lp/hotel/page.tsx` | Hotel procurement landing page |
| `app/[locale]/lp/back-pain/page.tsx` | Back pain relief landing page |
| `app/[locale]/lp/luxury/page.tsx` | Luxury home landing page |
| `components/LpLeadForm.tsx` | Inline lead capture form for LPs |
| `components/LeadCaptureModal.tsx` | Exit-intent + 30s slide-up modal |

### Backend additions
- `Event` model + `Lead` model + migration
- `POST /api/events`, `POST /api/leads`, `GET /api/admin/stats`
- Three new controllers: `eventController`, `leadController`, `adminController`

### Key UX features
- **Language switcher**: `ä¸­ / EN / æ—¥` buttons in Navbar, preserves current path on switch
- **Price anchoring**: Every product card shows hotel price (strikethrough) vs direct price + "çœÂ¥X" green badge
- **Analytics funnel**: view_homepage â†’ view_product â†’ add_to_cart â†’ begin_checkout â†’ purchase, all tracked
- **Admin dashboard** at `/zh/admin`: 4 stat cards + funnel bar chart + leads table
- **Lead capture modal**: slides up from bottom-right, deduped per session, triggers on exit-intent or 30s

## Summary of Changes

### Backend (4 files modified, 3 files created)

**Schema** -- `backend/prisma/schema.prisma`
- Added `stripeSessionId` (unique, nullable) and `paymentIntentId` (nullable) to the `Order` model
- Ran `prisma db push` and `prisma generate`

**Dependencies** -- `backend/package.json`
- Installed `stripe` SDK

**Environment** -- `backend/.env`
- Added `STRIPE_SECRET_KEY`, `STRIPE_WEBHOOK_SECRET`, `FRONTEND_URL`

**New: Stripe client** -- `backend/src/lib/stripe.ts`
- Singleton Stripe instance initialized from env var

**New: Checkout route** -- `backend/src/routes/checkout.ts`
- `POST /api/checkout` -- validates products from DB, recalculates price server-side, creates a pending order, creates a Stripe Checkout Session with `line_items`, saves `stripeSessionId`, returns the Stripe URL
- `GET /api/checkout/session-status` -- looks up an order by its `stripeSessionId` for the success page

**New: Webhook route** -- `backend/src/routes/webhook.ts`
- `POST /api/webhook` -- verifies Stripe signature, handles `checkout.session.completed` (updates order to "paid", saves `paymentIntentId`) and `checkout.session.expired` (marks order "cancelled")

**Server wiring** -- `backend/src/index.ts`
- Webhook route mounted BEFORE `express.json()` with `express.raw()` for signature verification
- Checkout route mounted after JSON middleware

### Frontend (6 files modified, 3 files created)

**API client** -- `frontend/lib/api.ts`
- Added `createCheckoutSession()` and `fetchSessionStatus()` functions

**Cart Drawer** -- `frontend/components/CartDrawer.tsx`
- Checkout now calls `createCheckoutSession()` and redirects to Stripe via `window.location.href`
- Cart is NOT cleared until the success page (so items are preserved if user cancels)
- Button text changes to "æ­£åœ¨è·³è½¬åˆ°æ”¯ä»˜é¡µé¢..." during loading
- Removed unused `useRouter` import

**Product Detail** -- both `app/[locale]/products/[id]/ProductDetailClient.tsx` and `app/products/[id]/ProductDetailClient.tsx`
- "Buy Now" now calls `createCheckoutSession()` and redirects to Stripe
- Loading text updated to indicate payment redirect
- Removed unused `useRouter`

**Orders page** -- `app/[locale]/orders/page.tsx`
- Status badge now shows "å·²æ”¯ä»˜" (green) for paid orders and "å·²å–æ¶ˆ" (red) for cancelled ones

**New: Success page** -- `frontend/app/[locale]/checkout/success/page.tsx`
- Reads `session_id` from URL, polls backend for order status (handles webhook race condition)
- Clears cart on mount
- Shows order summary with payment status badge

**New: Cancel page** -- `frontend/app/[locale]/checkout/cancel/page.tsx`
- Clean "payment cancelled" page with CTAs to return to products

**Environment** -- `frontend/.env.local`
- Added `NEXT_PUBLIC_STRIPE_PUBLISHABLE_KEY` and `NEXT_PUBLIC_API_URL`

### To activate

1. Replace `sk_test_REPLACE_WITH_YOUR_KEY` in `backend/.env` with your Stripe test secret key
2. Replace `whsec_REPLACE_WITH_YOUR_SECRET` with your webhook signing secret (from Stripe Dashboard or `stripe listen --forward-to localhost:4000/api/webhook`)
3. Replace `pk_test_REPLACE_WITH_YOUR_KEY` in `frontend/.env.local` with your publishable key
4. Test with Stripe test card `4242 4242 4242 4242`

const API = process.env.NEXT_PUBLIC_API_URL || "http://localhost:4000";

function getSessionId(): string {
  if (typeof window === "undefined") return "";
  try {
    let id = localStorage.getItem("_rsid");
    if (!id) {
      id = crypto.randomUUID();
      localStorage.setItem("_rsid", id);
    }
    return id;
  } catch {
    return "";
  }
}

export function trackEvent(type: string, productId?: number): void {
  if (typeof window === "undefined") return;
  const sessionId = getSessionId();
  if (!sessionId) return;

  fetch(&#96;${API}/api/events&#96;, {
    method: "POST",
    headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
    body: JSON.stringify({
      type,
      productId: productId ?? null,
      sessionId,
      userAgent: navigator.userAgent,
    }),
  }).catch(() =&gt; {});
}

## What was implemented

### New files

**`frontend/components/GoogleAnalytics.tsx`**
Injects the GA4 `gtag.js` script via `next/script` with `strategy="afterInteractive"`. Returns `null` in any non-production environment or when `NEXT_PUBLIC_GA_ID` is not set â€” zero performance cost in dev.

**`frontend/hooks/useScrollDepth.ts`**
A lightweight hook that attaches a passive `scroll` listener and fires `trackEvent('scroll_depth_25/50/75/100')` at each milestone. Each milestone fires exactly once per component mount and resets on navigation.

**`frontend/types/gtag.d.ts`**
Global TypeScript declaration for `window.gtag` and `window.dataLayer` so analytics calls compile cleanly without `any` casts.

**`frontend/.env.local.example`**
Documents all required environment variables including `NEXT_PUBLIC_GA_ID`.

### Modified files

**`frontend/lib/analytics.ts`**
- Maps internal event names to GA4 standard names (`view_product` â†’ `view_item`, etc.)
- Every `trackEvent` call now also fires `window.gtag('event', ...)` when available
- Dev mode prints styled `[Analytics]` console logs with event name and product ID
- New `trackCTAClick(label, productId?)` helper for named CTA instrumentation

**`frontend/app/[locale]/layout.tsx`**
Added `<GoogleAnalytics />` inside `<html>` so it loads once for every page.

**`frontend/app/[locale]/products/[id]/ProductDetailClient.tsx`**
- `useScrollDepth()` called at component top â€” tracks how far users scroll the product page
- `handleBuyNow` now fires `begin_checkout` + `trackCTAClick` before redirecting
- All four CTA buttons (desktop hero, desktop sticky, mobile sticky, final CTA section) each pass a unique label (`buy_now_desktop`, `add_to_cart_mobile_sticky`, etc.) so you can see exactly which placement drives conversions

### To activate GA4
Add your Measurement ID to `frontend/.env.local`:
```
NEXT_PUBLIC_GA_ID=G-XXXXXXXXXX
```

## Prerequisites â€” Push your code to GitHub first

Before anything else, your code must be in a GitHub repository.

```bash
# In D:\Shopline
git init
git add .
git commit -m "initial production build"
git remote add origin https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/shopline.git
git push -u origin main
```

---

## STEP 1 â€” Deploy Backend to Railway

**1.1 â€” Create Railway project**

1. Go to [railway.app](https://railway.app) â†’ Sign in with GitHub â†’ **New Project**
2. Click **Deploy from GitHub repo** â†’ select your `shopline` repo
3. Railway asks for the root directory â€” type: `backend`
4. Click **Deploy Now** (it will fail on the first attempt without env vars â€” that's fine)

**1.2 â€” Add PostgreSQL database**

1. In your Railway project dashboard, click **+ New** (top right)
2. Select **Database** â†’ **Add PostgreSQL**
3. Railway creates a Postgres instance and **automatically** sets `DATABASE_URL` in your backend service â€” you do NOT need to copy it manually

**1.3 â€” Set environment variables**

In Railway â†’ click your **backend service** (not the Postgres service) â†’ **Variables** tab â†’ click **Raw Editor** and paste:

```
STRIPE_SECRET_KEY=sk_test_...
STRIPE_WEBHOOK_SECRET=whsec_placeholder
FRONTEND_URL=https://shopline.vercel.app
```

> Leave `DATABASE_URL` alone â€” Railway auto-manages it. Leave `PORT` alone too.
> Use `sk_test_...` now; swap for `sk_live_...` when ready for real money.

**1.4 â€” Set build & start commands**

Railway â†’ backend service â†’ **Settings** tab â†’ scroll to **Deploy**:

| Setting | Value |
|---|---|
| Build Command | `npm install && npm run build` |
| Start Command | `npm run db:migrate:deploy && npm start` |

**1.5 â€” Trigger a deploy**

Click **Deploy** or push any commit â€” Railway will now build TypeScript, generate the Prisma client, run migrations against PostgreSQL, and start the server.

Watch the **Logs** tab. A successful start looks like:
```
Server running on http://localhost:XXXX
```

**1.6 â€” Get your Railway URL**

Railway â†’ backend service â†’ **Settings** â†’ **Domains** â†’ click **Generate Domain**. Your URL will be something like:
```
https://shopline-production.up.railway.app
```

**1.7 â€” Verify backend is alive**

Open in browser:
```
https://shopline-production.up.railway.app/health
```
You must see: `{"status":"ok"}`

If you see an error, check **Logs** in Railway.

---

## STEP 2 â€” Deploy Frontend to Vercel

**2.1 â€” Import project**

1. Go to [vercel.com](https://vercel.com) â†’ **Add New Project**
2. Import your `shopline` GitHub repo
3. When Vercel asks for the framework: it auto-detects **Next.js**
4. Set **Root Directory** to: `frontend`
5. **Do not click Deploy yet** â€” set env vars first

**2.2 â€” Set environment variables**

In the same import screen, scroll down to **Environment Variables** and add these three:

| Name | Value |
|---|---|
| `NEXT_PUBLIC_API_URL` | `https://shopline-production.up.railway.app` (your Railway URL, no trailing slash) |
| `NEXT_PUBLIC_STRIPE_PUBLISHABLE_KEY` | `pk_test_...` (from Stripe Dashboard â†’ API Keys) |
| `NEXT_PUBLIC_GA_ID` | `G-XXXXXXXXXX` (optional â€” your GA4 ID, or leave blank) |

**2.3 â€” Deploy**

Click **Deploy**. Vercel runs `npm run build`. The build takes 1â€“3 minutes.

Your frontend URL will be something like:
```
https://shopline.vercel.app
```

**2.4 â€” Update FRONTEND_URL in Railway**

Now that you have the Vercel URL, go back to Railway â†’ backend service â†’ Variables â†’ update:
```
FRONTEND_URL=https://shopline.vercel.app
```

Railway redeploys automatically.

---

## STEP 3 â€” Set Up Stripe Webhook

This step is what makes orders actually update to "paid" after a successful payment.

**3.1 â€” Create the webhook endpoint in Stripe**

1. Go to [dashboard.stripe.com/webhooks](https://dashboard.stripe.com/webhooks)
2. Click **Add endpoint**
3. **Endpoint URL**: `https://shopline-production.up.railway.app/api/webhook`
4. Click **Select events** â†’ search for and select:
   - `checkout.session.completed`
   - `checkout.session.expired`
5. Click **Add endpoint**

**3.2 â€” Copy the signing secret**

After saving, click your new endpoint â†’ click **Reveal** next to **Signing secret**. Copy the value starting with `whsec_`.

**3.3 â€” Add secret to Railway**

Railway â†’ backend service â†’ Variables â†’ update:
```
STRIPE_WEBHOOK_SECRET=whsec_REAL_VALUE_HERE
```

Railway redeploys in ~30 seconds.

**3.4 â€” Test the webhook**

In Stripe Dashboard â†’ Webhooks â†’ your endpoint â†’ click **Send test webhook** â†’ choose `checkout.session.completed` â†’ **Send**.

In Railway â†’ Logs, you should see:
```
Order paid â€” session cs_test_xxx
```

---

## STEP 4 â€” Connect Custom Domain (Aliyun DNS)

**4.1 â€” Add domain to Vercel**

1. Vercel â†’ your project â†’ **Settings** â†’ **Domains** â†’ **Add**
2. Enter: `www.yourdomain.com` â†’ click **Add**
3. Vercel shows you a CNAME record to add

**4.2 â€” Configure Aliyun DNS**

1. Go to [Aliyun DNS Console](https://dns.console.aliyun.com/)
2. Find your domain â†’ click **Resolve Settings** (è§£æè®¾ç½®)
3. Click **Add Record** (æ·»åŠ è®°å½•):

| Field | Value |
|---|---|
| Record type (è®°å½•ç±»å‹) | CNAME |
| Host (ä¸»æœºè®°å½•) | `www` |
| Record value (è®°å½•å€¼) | `cname.vercel-dns.com` |
| TTL | 600 (default) |

4. Click **Confirm**. DNS propagation takes 5â€“30 minutes.

**4.3 â€” Add apex domain redirect (optional)**

To redirect `yourdomain.com` â†’ `www.yourdomain.com`, add a second record in Aliyun:

| Field | Value |
|---|---|
| Record type | CNAME |
| Host | `@` |
| Record value | `cname.vercel-dns.com` |

**4.4 â€” Update FRONTEND_URL in Railway**

Once the domain is live, update Railway:
```
FRONTEND_URL=https://www.yourdomain.com
```

## STEP 5 â€” Full Verification Checklist

Run through this after deployment. Check each item in order.

**API & Database**

```
[ ] Open https://YOUR-RAILWAY-URL/health â†’ must return {"status":"ok"}
[ ] Open https://YOUR-VERCEL-URL/ â†’ homepage loads, products appear
[ ] Products show real images (R666, R888, R999)
[ ] Open browser DevTools â†’ Network tab â†’ verify API calls go to Railway URL, not localhost
```

**Stripe Payments (use test mode first)**

Use Stripe test card: `4242 4242 4242 4242`, any expiry, any CVC.

```
[ ] Open a product page â†’ click "ç«‹å³è´­ä¹°" â†’ Stripe Checkout page opens
[ ] Enter test card â†’ complete payment
[ ] Redirected to /checkout/success with order summary
[ ] In Railway Logs: "Order paid â€” session cs_xxx" appears
[ ] In Stripe Dashboard â†’ Payments: payment shows as "Succeeded"
[ ] In Stripe Dashboard â†’ Webhooks â†’ your endpoint: last event shows "200"
```

**CORS (frontend can reach backend)**

```
[ ] Open DevTools console on the Vercel site â†’ no CORS errors in red
[ ] Cart drawer opens, adds items, checkout works end-to-end
```

**Analytics (if GA4 configured)**

```
[ ] In GA4 Dashboard â†’ Realtime â†’ see yourself as an active user
[ ] View a product page â†’ GA4 should fire "view_item" event
[ ] Check Realtime Events in GA4 for add_to_cart, begin_checkout
```

**Production Stripe (when ready for real payments)**

Only do this after testing everything in test mode:

1. Stripe Dashboard â†’ toggle from **Test mode** to **Live mode** (top right)
2. Get live keys: `pk_live_...` and `sk_live_...`
3. Update Railway: `STRIPE_SECRET_KEY=sk_live_...`
4. Update Vercel: `NEXT_PUBLIC_STRIPE_PUBLISHABLE_KEY=pk_live_...`
5. Create a new webhook endpoint in Live mode (same URL, same events) and get new `whsec_...`
6. Update Railway: `STRIPE_WEBHOOK_SECRET=whsec_live_...`

## Quick Reference â€” All Environment Variables

**Railway (backend)**

| Variable | Where to get it |
|---|---|
| `DATABASE_URL` | Auto-injected by Railway Postgres |
| `STRIPE_SECRET_KEY` | Stripe Dashboard â†’ API Keys â†’ Secret key |
| `STRIPE_WEBHOOK_SECRET` | Stripe Dashboard â†’ Webhooks â†’ your endpoint â†’ Signing secret |
| `FRONTEND_URL` | Your Vercel URL (update after domain setup) |

**Vercel (frontend)**

| Variable | Where to get it |
|---|---|
| `NEXT_PUBLIC_API_URL` | Your Railway service URL |
| `NEXT_PUBLIC_STRIPE_PUBLISHABLE_KEY` | Stripe Dashboard â†’ API Keys â†’ Publishable key |
| `NEXT_PUBLIC_GA_ID` | GA4 â†’ Admin â†’ Data Streams â†’ your stream â†’ Measurement ID |

operator with the&#96;PrismaConfig&#96; type:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport \"dotenv/config\";\nimport type { PrismaConfig } from \"prisma\";\nimport { env } from \"prisma/config\";\n\nexport default {\n  schema: \"prisma/schema.prisma\",\n  migrations: {\n    path: \"prisma/migrations\",\n    seed: \"tsx prisma/seed.ts\",\n  },\n  datasource: {\n    url: env(\"DATABASE_URL\"),\n  },\n} satisfies PrismaConfig;\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n## Configuration interface\n\nHere is a simplified version of the&#96;PrismaConfig&#96; type:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nexport declare type PrismaConfig = {\n  // Whether features with an unstable API are enabled.\n  experimental: {\n    externalTables: boolean;\n  };\n\n  // The path to the schema file, or path to a folder that shall be recursively searched for *.prisma files.\n  schema?: string;\n\n  // Configuration for Prisma migrations.\n  migrations?: {\n    path: string;\n    seed: string;\n    initShadowDb: string;\n  };\n\n  // Configuration for the database view entities.\n  views?: {\n    path: string;\n  };\n\n  // Configuration for the &#96;typedSql&#96; preview feature.\n  typedSql?: {\n    path: string;\n  };\n\n  // Database connection configuration\n  datasource?: {\n    url: string;\n    shadowDatabaseUrl?: string;\n  };\n};\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n## Supported file extensions\n\nPrisma Config files can be named as&#96;prisma.config.*&#96; or&#96;.config/prisma.*&#96; with the extensions&#96;js&#96;,&#96;ts&#96;,&#96;mjs&#96;,&#96;cjs&#96;,&#96;mts&#96;, or&#96;cts&#96;. Other extensions are supported to ensure compatibility with different TypeScript compiler settings.\n\nRecommendation\n\n- Use&#96;.config/prisma.ts&#96; for larger TypeScript projects with multiple configuration files (following the [.config directory proposal](https://github.com/pi0/config-dir)).\n- Use&#96;prisma.config.ts&#96; for small TypeScript projects.\n\n## Options reference\n\n### schema\n\nConfigures how Prisma ORM locates and loads your schema file(s). Can be a file or folder path. Relative paths are resolved relative to the&#96;prisma.config.ts&#96; file location. See [here](https://pris.ly/docs/orm/prisma-schema/overview/location#multi-file-prisma-schema) for more info about schema location options.\n\n| Property | Type | Required | Default |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| &#96;schema&#96; | &#96;string&#96; | No | &#96;./prisma/schema.prisma&#96; and&#96;./schema.prisma&#96; |\n\n### tables.external and enums.external\n\nThese options declare tables and enums in your database that are managed externally (not by Prisma Migrate). You can still query them with Prisma Client, but they will be ignored by migrations.\n\n| Property | Type | Required | Default |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| &#96;tables.external&#96; | &#96;string[]&#96; | No | &#96;[]&#96; |\n| &#96;enums.external&#96; | &#96;string[]&#96; | No | &#96;[]&#96; |\n\nExample:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport \"dotenv/config\";\nimport { defineConfig, env } from \"prisma/config\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  schema: \"prisma/schema.prisma\",\n  migrations: {\n    path: \"prisma/migrations\",\n  },\n  datasource: {\n    url: env(\"DATABASE_URL\"),\n  },\n  experimental: {\n    externalTables: true,\n  },\n  tables: {\n    external: [\"public.users\"],\n  },\n  enums: {\n    external: [\"public.role\"],\n  },\n});\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nLearn more about the [externalTables feature here](https://pris.ly/docs/orm/prisma-schema/data-model/externally-managed-tables).\n\n### migrations.path\n\nThe path to the directory where Prisma should store migration files, and look for them.\n\n| Property | Type | Required | Default |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| &#96;migrations.path&#96; | &#96;string&#96; | No | none |\n\n### migrations.seed\n\nDefines the command to run when executing&#96;npx prisma db seed&#96;. Seeding is only triggered explicitly via this command.\n\n| Property | Type | Required | Default |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| &#96;migrations.seed&#96; | &#96;string&#96; | No | none |\n\nExample:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport \"dotenv/config\";\nimport { defineConfig, env } from \"prisma/config\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  schema: \"prisma/schema.prisma\",\n  migrations: {\n    path: \"prisma/migrations\",\n    seed: \"tsx db/seed.ts\",\n  },\n  datasource: {\n    url: env(\"DATABASE_URL\"),\n  },\n});\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### migrations.initShadowDb\n\nThis option allows you to define SQL statements that Prisma runs on the shadow database before creating migrations. It is useful when working with [external managed tables](https://pris.ly/docs/orm/prisma-schema/data-model/externally-managed-tables), as Prisma needs to know about the structure of these tables to correctly generate migrations.\n\n| Property | Type | Required | Default |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| &#96;migrations.initShadowDb&#96; | &#96;string&#96; | No | none |\n\nExample:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport \"dotenv/config\";\nimport { defineConfig, env } from \"prisma/config\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  schema: \"prisma/schema.prisma\",\n  migrations: {\n    path: \"prisma/migrations\",\n    initShadowDb: &#96;\n      CREATE TABLE public.users (id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY);\n    &#96;,\n  },\n  datasource: {\n    url: env(\"DATABASE_URL\"),\n  },\n  experimental: {\n    externalTables: true,\n  },\n  tables: {\n    external: [\"public.users\"],\n  },\n});\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nLearn more about the [externalTables feature here](https://pris.ly/docs/orm/prisma-schema/data-model/externally-managed-tables).\n\n### views.path\n\nThe path to the directory where Prisma should look for the SQL view definitions.\n\n| Property | Type | Required | Default |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| &#96;views.path&#96; | &#96;string&#96; | No | none |\n\n### typedSql.path\n\nThe path to the directory where Prisma should look for the SQL files used for generating typings via [typedSql](https://pris.ly/docs/orm/prisma-client/using-raw-sql/typedsql).\n\n| Property | Type | Required | Default |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| &#96;typedSql.path&#96; | &#96;string&#96; | No | none |\n\n### experimental\n\nEnables specific experimental features in the Prisma CLI.\n\n| Property | Type | Required | Default |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| &#96;externalTables&#96; | &#96;boolean&#96; | No | &#96;false&#96; |\n\nExample:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport \"dotenv/config\";\nimport { defineConfig, env } from \"prisma/config\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  schema: \"prisma/schema.prisma\",\n  migrations: {\n    path: \"prisma/migrations\",\n  },\n  datasource: {\n    url: env(\"DATABASE_URL\"),\n  },\n  experimental: {\n    externalTables: true,\n  },\n});\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nIf you use the&#96;externalTables&#96; feature without enabling the experimental flag, Prisma will throw an error:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nFailed to load config file \"~\" as a TypeScript/JavaScript module. Error: Error: The &#96;externalTables&#96; configuration requires &#96;experimental.externalTables&#96; to be set to &#96;true&#96;.\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### datasource.url\n\nConnection URL including authentication info. Uses [the syntax provided by the database](https://pris.ly/docs/orm/reference/connection-urls#format).\n\n| Property | Type | Required | Default |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| &#96;datasource.url&#96; | &#96;string&#96; | Yes | &#96;''&#96; |\n\nExample:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport \"dotenv/config\";\nimport { defineConfig, env } from \"prisma/config\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  schema: \"prisma/schema.prisma\",\n  migrations: {\n    path: \"prisma/migrations\",\n  },\n  datasource: {\n    url: env(\"DATABASE_URL\"),\n  },\n});\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### datasource.shadowDatabaseUrl\n\nConnection URL to the shadow database used by Prisma Migrate. Allows you to use a cloud-hosted database as the shadow database.\n\n| Property | Type | Required | Default |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| &#96;datasource.shadowDatabaseUrl&#96; | &#96;string&#96; | No | &#96;''&#96; |\n\n### datasource.directUrl (Removed)\n\nRemoved in Prisma ORM v7\n\nThe&#96;datasource.directUrl&#96; property has been removed in Prisma ORM v7 in favor of the&#96;url&#96; property.\n\nFor Prisma ORM v6.19 and earlier\n\nConnection URL for direct connection to the database.\n\nIf you use a connection pooler URL in the&#96;url&#96; argument (for example, pgBouncer), Prisma CLI commands that require a direct connection to the database use the URL in the&#96;directUrl&#96; argument.\n\nThe&#96;directUrl&#96; property is supported by Prisma Studio from version 5.1.0 upwards. The&#96;directUrl&#96; property is not needed when using [Prisma Postgres](https://pris.ly/docs/postgres) database.\n\n| Property | Type | Required | Default |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| &#96;datasource.directUrl&#96; | &#96;string&#96; | No | &#96;''&#96; |\n\n### adapter (Removed)\n\nRemoved in Prisma ORM v7\n\nThe&#96;adapter&#96; property has been removed in Prisma ORM v7. Migrations for driver adapters work automatically without additional configuration in&#96;prisma.config.ts&#96; as of Prisma ORM v7.\n\nFor Prisma ORM v6.19 and earlier\n\nA function that returns a Prisma driver adapter instance which is used by the Prisma CLI to run migrations. The function should return a&#96;Promise&#96; that resolves to a valid Prisma driver adapter.\n\n| Property | Type | Required | Default |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| &#96;adapter&#96; | &#96;() =&gt; Promise &#96; | No | none |\n\nExample using the Prisma ORM D1 driver adapter:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport path from \"node:path\";\nimport type { PrismaConfig } from \"prisma\";\nimport { PrismaD1 } from \"@prisma/adapter-d1\";\n\nexport default {\n  experimental: {\n    adapter: true,\n  },\n  engine: \"js\",\n  schema: path.join(\"prisma\", \"schema.prisma\"),\n  async adapter() {\n    return new PrismaD1({\n      CLOUDFLARE_D1_TOKEN: process.env.CLOUDFLARE_D1_TOKEN,\n      CLOUDFLARE_ACCOUNT_ID: process.env.CLOUDFLARE_ACCOUNT_ID,\n      CLOUDFLARE_DATABASE_ID: process.env.CLOUDFLARE_DATABASE_ID,\n    });\n  },\n} satisfies PrismaConfig;\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nAs of [Prisma ORM v6.11.0](https://github.com/prisma/prisma/releases/tag/6.11.0), the D1 adapter has been renamed from&#96;PrismaD1HTTP&#96; to&#96;PrismaD1&#96;.\n\n### engine (Removed)\n\nRemoved in Prisma ORM v7\n\nThe&#96;engine&#96; property has been removed in Prisma ORM v7.\n\nFor Prisma ORM v6.19 and earlier\n\nConfigure the schema engine your project should use.\n\n| Property | Type | Required | Default |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| &#96;engine&#96; | &#96;classic&#96; or&#96;js&#96; | No | &#96;classic&#96; |\n\nBy default it is set to use the classic engine, which requires that&#96;datasource&#96; be set in your&#96;prisma.config.ts&#96;.\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport \"dotenv/config\";\nimport path from \"node:path\";\nimport { defineConfig, env } from \"prisma/config\";\nexport default defineConfig({\n  engine: \"classic\",\n  datasource: {\n    url: env(\"DATABASE_URL\"),\n  },\n  schema: path.join(\"prisma\", \"schema.prisma\"),\n});\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### studio (Removed)\n\nRemoved in Prisma ORM v7\n\nThe&#96;studio&#96; property has been removed in Prisma ORM v7. To run Prisma Studio, use:\n\nnpm\n\npnpm\n\nyarn\n\nbun\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nnpx prisma studio --config ./prisma.config.ts\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nPrisma Studio now uses the connection configuration from the&#96;datasource&#96; property automatically. See the [Prisma Studio documentation](https://pris.ly/docs/orm/reference/prisma-cli-reference#studio) for more details.\n\nFor Prisma ORM v6.19 and earlier\n\nConfigures how Prisma Studio connects to your database. See sub-options below for details.\n\n| Property | Type | Required | Default |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| &#96;studio&#96; | &#96;object&#96; | No | none |\n\n#### studio.adapter (Removed)\n\nA function that returns a Prisma driver adapter instance. The function receives an&#96;env&#96; parameter containing environment variables and should return a&#96;Promise&#96; that resolves to a valid Prisma driver adapter.\n\n| Property | Type | Required | Default |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| &#96;studio.adapter &#96; | &#96;(env: Env) =&gt; Promise &#96; | No | none |\n\nExample using the Prisma ORM LibSQL driver adapter:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport type { PrismaConfig } from \"prisma\";\n\nexport default {\n  experimental: {\n    studio: true,\n  },\n  engine: \"js\",\n  studio: {\n    adapter: async (env: Env) =&gt; {\n      const { PrismaLibSQL } = await import(\"@prisma/adapter-libsql\");\n      const { createClient } = await import(\"@libsql/client\");\n\n      const libsql = createClient({\n        url: env.DOTENV_PRISMA_STUDIO_LIBSQL_DATABASE_URL,\n      });\n      return new PrismaLibSQL(libsql);\n    },\n  },\n} satisfies PrismaConfig;\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n## Common patterns\n\n### Setting up your project\n\nTo get started with Prisma Config, create a&#96;prisma.config.ts&#96; file in your project root. You can use either of these approaches:\n\nUsing&#96;defineConfig&#96;:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport \"dotenv/config\";\nimport { defineConfig, env } from \"prisma/config\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  schema: \"prisma/schema.prisma\",\n  migrations: {\n    path: \"prisma/migrations\",\n  },\n  datasource: {\n    url: env(\"DATABASE_URL\"),\n  },\n});\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nUsing TypeScript types:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport \"dotenv/config\";\nimport type { PrismaConfig } from \"prisma\";\nimport { env } from \"prisma/config\";\n\nexport default {\n  schema: \"prisma/schema.prisma\",\n  migrations: {\n    path: \"prisma/migrations\",\n  },\n  datasource: {\n    url: env(\"DATABASE_URL\"),\n  },\n} satisfies PrismaConfig;\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### Using environment variables\n\nEnvironment variables from&#96;.env&#96; files need to be loaded explicitly. The&#96;prisma init&#96; command generates a config that includes&#96;import 'dotenv/config'&#96; by default.\n\n#### Using dotenv (Recommended for Prisma ORM v7)\n\n1. Install the&#96;dotenv&#96; package:\n\nnpm\n\npnpm\n\nyarn\n\nbun\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nnpm install dotenv\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n1. Import&#96;dotenv/config&#96; at the top of your&#96;prisma.config.ts&#96; file:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport \"dotenv/config\";\nimport { defineConfig, env } from \"prisma/config\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  schema: \"prisma/schema.prisma\",\n  migrations: {\n    path: \"prisma/migrations\",\n    seed: \"tsx prisma/seed.ts\",\n  },\n  datasource: {\n    url: env(\"DATABASE_URL\"),\n  },\n});\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n#### Using Node.js v20+ or tsx with --env-file flag\n\nIf using Node.js v20+ or&#96;tsx&#96;, you can pass a&#96;--env-file&#96; flag to automatically load environment variables:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\ntsx --env-title=\".env\" src/index.ts\ntsx watch --env-title=\".env\" --env-title=\".local.env\" src/index.ts\ntsx --env-title=\".env\" ./prisma/seed.ts\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n#### Using Bun\n\nFor Bun,&#96;.env&#96; files are automatically loaded without additional configuration. The&#96;import 'dotenv/config'&#96; line that&#96;prisma init&#96; generates is not needed when using Bun and can be safely removed from your&#96;prisma.config.ts&#96; file.\n\nWhen running Prisma CLI commands with Bun, use the&#96;--bun&#96; flag (e.g.,&#96;bunx --bun prisma init&#96;) to ensure Prisma uses the Bun runtime instead of falling back to Node.js.\n\n#### Type-safe environment variables\n\nUse the&#96;env()&#96; helper function to provide type-safe access to environment variables:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport \"dotenv/config\";\nimport { defineConfig, env } from \"prisma/config\";\n\ntype Env = {\n  DATABASE_URL: string;\n};\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  schema: \"prisma/schema.prisma\",\n  migrations: {\n    path: \"prisma/migrations\",\n  },\n  datasource: {\n    url: env&lt;Env&gt;(\"DATABASE_URL\"),\n  },\n});\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n#### Handling optional environment variables\n\nThe&#96;env()&#96; helper function from&#96;prisma/config&#96; throws an error if the specified environment variable is not defined. This is important to understand because:\n\n- Commands like&#96;prisma generate&#96; don't need a database URL, but will still fail if&#96;env()&#96; throws an error when loading the config file\n- Only some commands actually need the&#96;datasource.url&#96; value (e.g.,&#96;prisma db *&#96;,&#96;prisma migrate *&#96;,&#96;prisma generate --sql&#96;)\n- Every Prisma CLI command loads the&#96;prisma.config.ts&#96; file\n\nFor example, if you run&#96;prisma generate&#96; without&#96;DATABASE_URL&#96; set, and your config uses&#96;env('DATABASE_URL')&#96;, you'll see:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nError: PrismaConfigEnvError: Missing required environment variable: DATABASE_URL\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nSolution: If your environment variable isn't guaranteed to exist (e.g., in CI/CD pipelines where you only run&#96;prisma generate&#96; for type-checking), don't use the&#96;env()&#96; helper. Instead, access the environment variable directly:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport \"dotenv/config\";\nimport { defineConfig } from \"prisma/config\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  schema: \"prisma/schema.prisma\",\n  migrations: {\n    path: \"prisma/migrations\",\n  },\n  datasource: {\n    url: process.env.DATABASE_URL!, // Or use: process.env.DATABASE_URL ?? '' to provide a fallback value\n  },\n});\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nUse the&#96;env()&#96; helper when you want to enforce that an environment variable exists. Use&#96;process.env&#96; directly when the variable may be optional depending on the command being run.\n\n### Using multi-file schemas\n\nIf you want to split your Prisma schema into multiple files, you need to specify the path to your Prisma schema folder via the&#96;schema&#96; property:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport path from \"node:path\";\nimport type { PrismaConfig } from \"prisma\";\n\nexport default {\n  schema: path.join(\"prisma\", \"schema\"),\n} satisfies PrismaConfig;\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nIn that case, your&#96;migrations&#96; directory must be located next to the&#96;.prisma&#96; file that defines the&#96;datasource&#96; block.\n\nFor example, assuming&#96;schema.prisma&#96; defines the&#96;datasource&#96;, here's how how need to place the migrations folder:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n# &#96;migrations&#96; and &#96;schema.prisma&#96; are on the same level\n.\nâ”œâ”€â”€ migrations\nâ”œâ”€â”€ models\nâ”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ posts.prisma\nâ”‚   â””â”€â”€ users.prisma\nâ””â”€â”€ schema.prisma\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n## Path resolution\n\nPrisma CLI commands such as&#96;prisma validate&#96; or&#96;prisma migrate&#96; use&#96;prisma.config.ts&#96;(or&#96;.config/prisma.ts&#96;) to locate your Prisma schema and other resources.\n\nKey rules:\n\n- The CLI must first find the config file itself, which depends on how Prisma is installed and the package manager used.\n- Paths defined in the config file (e.g.,&#96;schema&#96;,&#96;migrations&#96;) are always resolved relative to the location of the config file, not where you run the CLI command from.\n\n### Behavior with pnpm prisma\n\nWhen Prisma is installed locally and run via&#96;pnpm prisma&#96;, the config file is detected automatically whether you run the command from the project root or a subdirectory.\n\nExample project tree:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n.\nâ”œâ”€â”€ node_modules\nâ”œâ”€â”€ package.json\nâ”œâ”€â”€ prisma-custom\nâ”‚   â””â”€â”€ schema.prisma\nâ”œâ”€â”€ prisma.config.ts\nâ””â”€â”€ src\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nExample run from the project root:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\npnpm prisma validate\n# â†’ Loaded Prisma config from ./prisma.config.ts\n# â†’ Prisma schema loaded from prisma-custom/schema.prisma\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nExample run from a subdirectory:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\ncd src\npnpm prisma validate\n# â†’ Still finds prisma.config.ts and resolves schema correctly\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### Behavior with npx prisma or bunx --bun prisma\n\nWhen running via&#96;npx prisma&#96; or&#96;bunx --bun prisma&#96;, the CLI only detects the config file if the command is run from the project root (where&#96;package.json&#96; declares Prisma).\n\nThe&#96;--bun&#96; flag is required when using Bun to ensure Prisma runs with the Bun runtime. Without it, Prisma falls back to Node.js due to the&#96;#!/usr/bin/env node&#96; shebang in the CLI.\n\nExample run from the project root:\n\nnpm\n\npnpm\n\nyarn\n\nbun\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nnpx prisma validate\n# â†’ Works as expected\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nRun from a subdirectory (fails):\n\nnpm\n\npnpm\n\nyarn\n\nbun\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\ncd src\nnpx prisma validate\n# â†’ Error: Could not find Prisma Schema...\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nTo fix this, you can use the&#96;--config&#96; flag:\n\nnpm\n\npnpm\n\nyarn\n\nbun\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nnpx prisma validate --config ../prisma.config.ts\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### Global Prisma installations\n\nIf Prisma is installed globally (&#96;npm i -g prisma&#96;), it may not find your&#96;prisma.config.ts&#96; or&#96;prisma/config&#96; module by default. To avoid issues:\n\n- Or use&#96;prisma/config&#96; locally and pass&#96;--config&#96; to point to your config file.\n- Prefer local Prisma installations in your project.\n\n### Monorepos\n\n- If Prisma is installed in a subpackage (e.g.,&#96;./packages/db&#96;), run commands from that package directory or deeper.\n- If Prisma is installed in the workspace root,&#96;pnpm prisma&#96; will detect the config file from subdirectories.\n\n### Custom config location\n\nYou can specify a custom location for your config file when running Prisma CLI commands:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nprisma validate --config ./path/to/myconfig.ts\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n## Loading environment variables\n\nTo load environment variables, install the&#96;dotenv&#96; package and add&#96;import 'dotenv/config'&#96; at the top of your&#96;prisma.config.ts&#96; file.\n\nTo load environment variables in your Prisma application, you can use the&#96;prisma.config.ts&#96; file along with the&#96;env&#96; helper from&#96;prisma/config&#96;. This approach provides better type safety and configuration management.\n\nInstall the&#96;dotenv&#96; package:\n\nnpm\n\npnpm\n\nyarn\n\nbun\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nnpm install dotenv\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nCreate a&#96;.env&#96; file in your project root (if it doesn't exist) and add your database connection string:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nDATABASE_URL=\"your_database_connection_string_here\"\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nEnsure your&#96;prisma.config.ts&#96; This change aligns with the move to make the main Prisma Client as lean and open as possible. For instance, if you are using Prisma Postgres, you now need the&#96;@prisma/adapter-pg&#96; adapter. This also means the signature for creating a new Prisma Client has changed slightly:\n\nConnection pools have changed.\n\nDriver adapters use the connection pool settings from the underlying Node.js database driver, which may differ significantly from Prisma ORM v6 defaults. Keep your Accelerate URL in&#96;.env&#96;(for example&#96;DATABASE_URL=\"prisma://...\"&#96; or&#96;prisma+postgres://...&#96;).\n\nprisma.config.ts\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport \"dotenv/config\";\nimport { defineConfig, env } from \"prisma/config\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  schema: \"prisma/schema.prisma\",\n  datasource: {\n    url: env(\"DATABASE_URL\"),\n  },\n});\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n- If you prefer a separate direct URL for migrations, you can still use&#96;DIRECT_DATABASE_URL&#96; as aboveâ€”but it's optional for Accelerate users.\n\n1. Instantiate Prisma Client with the Accelerate URL and extension (no adapter):\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport { PrismaClient } from \"./generated/prisma/client\";\nimport { withAccelerate } from \"@prisma/extension-accelerate\";\n\nexport const prisma = new PrismaClient({\n  accelerateUrl: process.env.DATABASE_URL,\n}).$extends(withAccelerate());\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nIf you later switch away from Accelerate to direct TCP, provide the direct URL to the appropriate driver adapter (for example&#96;PrismaPg&#96;) instead of&#96;accelerateUrl&#96;.\n\n### SSL certificate validation changes\n\nSince Prisma ORM v7 uses&#96;node-pg&#96; instead of the Rust-based query engine, SSL certificate defaults have changed. In v7, you may encounter the following error:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nError: P1010: User was denied access on the database &lt;database&gt;\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nTo fix this, either keep the previous behavior:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nconst adapter = new PrismaPg({\n  connectionString: process.env.DATABASE_URL,\n  ssl: { rejectUnauthorized: false },\n});\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nOr properly configure your database certificates using&#96;node --use-openssl-ca&#96; or by setting the&#96;NODE_EXTRA_CA_CERTS&#96; environment variable.\n\nFor more details, see [GitHub issue #28795](https://github.com/prisma/prisma/issues/28795).\n\n### Environment variables\n\nIn Prisma ORM 7.0.0, environment variables are not loaded by default. You now configure your database URL, schema location, migration output, and custom seed scripts.\n\nThe&#96;prisma.config.ts&#96; file should be placed at the root of your project (where your&#96;package.json&#96; is located).\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport \"dotenv/config\";\nimport { defineConfig, env } from \"prisma/config\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  // the main entry for your schema\n  schema: \"prisma/schema.prisma\",\n  // where migrations should be generated\n  // what script to run for \"prisma db seed\"\n  migrations: {\n    path: \"prisma/migrations\",\n    seed: \"tsx prisma/seed.ts\",\n  },\n  // The database URL\n  datasource: {\n    // Type Safe env() helper\n    // Does not replace the need for dotenv\n    url: env(\"DATABASE_URL\"),\n  },\n});\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### Metrics removed\n\nThe Metrics preview feature was deprecated in [Prisma ORM 6.14.0](https://github.com/prisma/prisma/releases/tag/6.14.0) and has been removed for Prisma ORM 7.0.0. If you need this feature, you can use the underlying driver adapter for your database, or Client Extensions to make this information available.\n\nFor example, a basic&#96;totalQueries&#96; counter:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nconst total = 0;\nconst prisma = new PrismaClient().$extends({\n  client: {\n    $log: (s: string) =&gt; console.log(s),\n    async $totalQueries() {\n      return total;\n    },\n  },\n  query: {\n    $allModels: {\n      async $allOperations({ query, args }) {\n        total += 1;\n        return query(args);\n      },\n    },\n  },\n});\n\nasync function main() {\n  prisma.$log(\"Hello world\");\n  const totalQueries = await prisma.$totalQueries();\n  console.log(totalQueries);\n}\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### Mapped enum values in generated TypeScript\n\nReversion to Prisma 6 behavior\n\nThe mapped enum implementation that was initially planned for Prisma ORM v7 has been reverted. Mapped enum behavior now matches Prisma ORM v6 to avoid breaking changes. We plan to implement a similar feature in the future with different syntax.\n\nIn Prisma ORM v7, the generated TypeScript enum values use the schema names, not the mapped values. This maintains compatibility with Prisma ORM v6 behavior.\n\n#### Prisma ORM v6 behavior\n\nGiven this Prisma schema:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nenum SuggestionStatus {\n  PENDING  @map(\"pending\")\n  ACCEPTED @map(\"accepted\")\n  REJECTED @map(\"rejected\")\n}\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nIn v6, the generated TypeScript enum was:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nexport const SuggestionStatus = {\n  PENDING: \"PENDING\",\n  ACCEPTED: \"ACCEPTED\",\n  REJECTED: \"REJECTED\",\n} as const;\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n#### Prisma ORM v7 (reverted behavior)\n\nIn v7, the same schema generates the same TypeScript as v6:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nexport const SuggestionStatus = {\n  PENDING: \"PENDING\",\n  ACCEPTED: \"ACCEPTED\",\n  REJECTED: \"REJECTED\",\n} as const;\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nThis means that&#96;SuggestionStatus.PENDING&#96; evaluates to&#96;\"PENDING\"&#96;, not&#96;\"pending\"&#96;. The mapping is handled at the database level only.\n\n#### Migration steps\n\nNo migration is required for this change. The behavior now matches Prisma ORM v6, so existing code will continue to work as expected.\n\n### Client middleware removed\n\nThe client middleware API has been removed. If possible, use [Client Extensions](https://www.prisma.io/docs/orm/prisma-client/client-extensions).\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n// âŒ Old (removed)\nprisma.$use(async (params, next) =&gt; {\n  // middleware logic\n  return next(params);\n});\n// âœ… New (use extensions)\nconst prisma = new PrismaClient().$extends({\n  query: {\n    user: {\n      async findMany({ args, query }) {\n        // extension logic\n        return query(args);\n      },\n    },\n  },\n});\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### Seeding changes\n\nIn Prisma ORM v6 and earlier, running&#96;prisma migrate dev&#96; or&#96;prisma migrate reset&#96; would automatically execute your seed script after applying migrations. This automatic seeding behavior has been removed in Prisma ORM v7.\n\nTo seed your database in v7, you must explicitly run:\n\nnpm\n\npnpm\n\nyarn\n\nbun\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nnpx prisma db seed\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### Removed CLI flags\n\nThe&#96;--skip-generate&#96; flag was removed from&#96;prisma migrate dev&#96; and&#96;prisma db push&#96;. The&#96;--skip-seed&#96; flag was removed from&#96;prisma migrate dev&#96;.\n\n&#96;migrate dev&#96; and&#96;db push&#96; no longer run&#96;prisma generate&#96; automatically. You must run&#96;prisma generate&#96; explicitly to generate Prisma Client.\n\n### Removed db execute flags\n\nThe&#96;--schema&#96; and&#96;--url&#96; flags have been removed from the&#96;prisma db execute&#96; command. Previously, you could use&#96;--schema&#96; to specify the path to your Prisma schema file, or&#96;--url&#96; to specify the database URL directly. Now, the database connection must be configured in&#96;prisma.config.ts&#96;.\n\n#### Before (v6)\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n# Using --schema\nprisma db execute --file ./script.sql --schema prisma/schema.prisma\n\n# Using --url\nprisma db execute --file ./script.sql --url \"$DATABASE_URL\"\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n#### After (v7)\n\nConfigure your database connection in&#96;prisma.config.ts&#96; instead:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nimport \"dotenv/config\";\nimport { defineConfig, env } from \"prisma/config\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  schema: \"prisma/schema.prisma\",\n  datasource: {\n    url: env(\"DATABASE_URL\"),\n  },\n});\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nThen run the command without&#96;--schema&#96; or&#96;--url&#96;:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nprisma db execute --file ./script.sql\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### Migrate diff changes\n\nSeveral options have been removed from&#96;prisma migrate diff&#96; and replaced with new options that use&#96;prisma.config.ts&#96;:\n\n| Removed Option | Replacement |\n| --- | --- |\n| &#96;--from-url&#96; ## Root Cause

**Prisma 7 is a breaking upgrade.** It removed support for `url = env("DATABASE_URL")` inside `schema.prisma`'s `datasource` block â€” it's now a hard error (not a warning). It also requires a **driver adapter** to be passed to `PrismaClient` at runtime.

---

## Changes Made

### 1. `prisma/schema.prisma` â€” Removed `url` from datasource
```7:8:D:\Shopline\backend\prisma\schema.prisma
datasource db {
  provider = "postgresql"
}
```

### 2. `prisma.config.ts` (recreated correctly) â€” URL now lives here
```1:11:D:\Shopline\backend\prisma.config.ts
import "dotenv/config";
import { defineConfig, env } from "prisma/config";

export default defineConfig({
  schema: "prisma/schema.prisma",
  migrations: {
    path: "prisma/migrations",
  },
  datasource: {
    url: env("DATABASE_URL"),
  },
});
```

### 3. `src/prisma/client.ts` â€” Now uses `PrismaPg` adapter (required by Prisma 7)
```1:16:D:\Shopline\backend\src\prisma\client.ts
import { PrismaClient } from "../../generated/prisma";
import { PrismaPg } from "@prisma/adapter-pg";

function createPrismaClient() {
  const adapter = new PrismaPg({
    connectionString: process.env.DATABASE_URL,
  });
  return new PrismaClient({ adapter });
}
```

### 4. `prisma/seed.ts` â€” Also uses `PrismaPg` adapter

### 5. `railway.json` + `nixpacks.toml` â€” Railway monorepo detection config added
